Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Fatty Acid Desaturation on Plant Defenses Against Aphids
Award.AbstractNarration: Aphids are a common pest of plants that feed on plant sap, reducing crop yields and frequently transmitting plant-pathogenic viruses. Cultivation of crop varieties that are resistant to aphids is one of the most effective and environmentally sustainable approaches to aphid pest management. However, our ability to develop such cultivars is hampered by our limited knowledge of the genes and biochemical pathways that control how resistant or susceptible plants are to aphids and other sap-feeding pests. The goal of this project is to investigate how fatty acids in plants may regulate plant defenses against aphids. The investigators have determined that in two different plant species (tomato and Arabidopsis), mutations that cause loss of function of a particular fatty acid desaturase (FAD7) also dramatically inhibit aphid infestation. Thus, FAD7 appears to be a common regulator of plant susceptibility to aphids. Loss of function of FAD7 causes dramatic changes in the fatty acid composition of the foliage, and likely also alters production of a diverse array of oxylipins, a family of compounds derived from fatty acids. In tomato, mutation of FAD7 also appears to enhance accumulation of salicylic acid, a plant hormone known to mediate plant defenses against many pathogens. An emerging body of evidence indicates that fatty acids in plants regulate salicylic acid-dependent defenses and pathogen resistance, but the underlying mechanisms are not yet well-understood. This project will use molecular and biochemical approaches to investigate how fatty acids, salicylic acid, and specific oxylipins contribute to plant defenses against aphids, and how fatty acids regulate salicylic acid signaling. Ultimately, this project should enhance our understanding of plant defense and contribute to economically sustainable pest management. In addition, it will provide training for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, as well as internship opportunities for K12 science teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aphids are a large family of insects that feed on plant sap, and that as a group attack almost all of the world’s major crops.  Aphids can have a devastating impact on farmers’ yields if left unchecked, and some aphid species also have strong resistance to pesticides, making them difficult to control.  To address this problem, plant scientists have begun to identify plants that have natural defenses against aphids, and to enhance these defenses in crops. This approach of identifying and selecting for host plant resistance has proven to be a highly effective, economical, and environmentally-safe approach for controlling many insect pests and plant pathogens. However, our knowledge of aphid resistance and our arsenal of known plant defenses against aphids are still quite limited, and further research is needed to identify a diverse set of plant defenses that could be used to protect the many crops attacked by aphids. This project investigated potential sources of aphid resistance in tomato and mouse-ear cress, a plant in the cabbage family that is commonly used to study plant genetics.  We demonstrated that in both of these very different plant species, it is possible to suppress aphid numbers by modifying the types of fatty acids present in the leaves. Fatty acids are essential molecules used by plants and other organisms to make fats and many other chemicals. By shifting the balance between different fatty acids in the leaves, we were able to enhance the "alarm system" that is tripped when aphids attack. In response to aphids, tomato plants with modified fatty acid levels produced more salicylic acid, a plant hormone that resembles aspirin and that acts as a signal to trigger the plant to defend itself. This enhanced aphid resistance; on the other hand, if we suppressed salicylic acid levels or prevented the plants from responding to it, aphid infestations increased. This data demonstrated that salicylic acid helps protect plants from aphids, and is influenced by fatty acid levels in the plant. We also discovered that alpha-dioxygenase 1---an enzyme that converts fatty acids to protective chemicals called oxylipins---protects against aphid infestations in both tomato and mouse-ear cress.  The fact that we observed similar results in two quite different plant families---the tomato/potato family and the cabbage family---suggests that similar defenses might also be effective in other plants.  This project advanced our basic understanding of the plant "immune" system, and identified plant defenses that could possibly be utilized to manage aphid pests on crops. 

 

The project also promoted education and helped train the science and technology workforce that our society needs. Support from NSF allowed us to leverage funds for student training from many other sources; as a result, a total of 7 undergraduates and 9 graduate or postgraduate students were able to participate in this project. In addition to students from the University of Arkansas, this number included 4 interns from other colleges or universities, recruited through the George Washington Carver Program (2) and other student exchange programs.  Project alumni have gone on to successful careers in science, technology, and health care, including faculty positions (1 at a university, 1 at a community college), staff scientist positions at biotechnology companies (2), and enrollment in medical, pharmacy, and nursing schools. The project also supported education at the K-12 level. The PI helped create a two-day workshop on plant biotechnology for high school science teachers; this workshop trained 8 teachers and provided them with kits for hands-on science experiments in their classrooms.
